posts.author: AlexYeager

There are several levels here (some already identified) that the statement covers:
- They have no interest in publishing the game again, based on its performance during its previous run.
- They no longer have the license to the game, with rights reverting back to Rieneck and Stadler.
- They no longer have a license for the Ken Follet IP. (Note that these licenses are sometimes for a setting rather than a story, so efficiencies that could have existed when publishing multiple Kingsbridge titles go away with only one.)

I have no direct information about any of this, and the variety of possibilities makes it generally useless for me to speculate.

posts.author: davypi
posts.body:
jambistan wrote:

I got into the hobby around 2016, and literally everyone back then was talking about how great this game is with the hard-to-find expansion. I played it a couple of times, and it was just OK—never felt like I needed to own it...


Something that I've always found confusing is that I've had people tell me that the think Viticulture's multiple use of workers is unique. While technically Viticulture and Pillars do this differently, I always felt like Pillars did the multi-use thing first, and did it better. Realistically, what I think Viticulture did was make better use of multi-deck combo building. Arguably Agricola also did that first and did it better, but I think Viticulture is a more approachable game. But to your point, Pillars was genuinely doing something unique during the era it was released. However, specific to when you got into the hobby, worker placement was the hot mechanic from probably 2012-2015 and I think a fair number of games managed to ride that wave for a couple of years beyond. But if you came into the hobby in 2016, you were coming in when that wave was dying and also when designers were starting to get a better grasp how to meld Ameritrash and Euro mechanics together in a satisfying way (e.g. Great Western Trail, Grand Austria Hotel). Euro games now days are expected to have a wide space in terms of variable setup and be blended with some other mechanic (i.e. "pure" worker placements are uncommon anymore). Pillars doesn't really compete by these metrics, so I can understand why its fallen out of favor. But on the other hand, if you compare it to its contemporaries, I think its fair to say that it was somewhat ahead of its time by those same metrics.

I'm not sure how adding the expansion to the reprint would have helped. The extra abilities are nice, but they're only meant to be used in a 5 or 6 player game. The board feels too open if you use the expansion with 2 or 3 players. Playing it with 4 is a bit iffy IMHO. I don't think adding that it would sell players who dislike the variable turn order mechanic and, being brutally honest, the metal resource has balance problems and I think some rule changes to fix that might have been more prudent.

threads.title: The overview to read before reading rules / watching a rules teach for the first time

posts.author: netzer
posts.body:
Intro to these “overviews before rules” I do:
The goal is to make reading rules easier, for those who want to spend the time. Sounds weird? I'll try to explain...
I love a variety of games but I find there’s an issue with rulebooks. A catch 22 if you will.
Rulebooks (and rule teaches) must be exact, but that creates a lot of time a feeling of anxiety for people as they start reading and wondering “When will it all tie together for me?”, “when will I say ‘ok, THAT’S the game!’?”. Some rulebooks aren’t read or understood because of that, and it’s a shame as many times the game is simpler than was considered.
To prevent that anxiety you need an overview which tells the story of the game (be it in written or video format). You tell a story differently than the way someone explains exact rules. The problem is that rulebooks cannot contain such an overview as it will make them too long, or feel like you’re reading rules twice – hence the catch. But some people do want to spend a few minutes to get the fuller overview of the game, and then dive into the actual rules.
So this is what I did here - a separate thing that comes "before reading rules". I would’ve preferred to do this as a video, but right now it’s a high quality youtube channel venture I wasn’t able to raise on my own (in high enough quality). I hope at some point I will move to video format.
And again, it’s an overview, so the decision whether or not to be exact in details or stay in high level is only determined if I felt, from my experience, that it contributed to the ease of reading the rules after reading this overview and how much clearer they became

Pillars of the Earth

The goal is to finish the game with the most points after 6 rounds.

At the end of each round, you will have “craftsmen” cards that basically convert resources to points. Every player starts with 3 of them, and a maximum of 5 at any given time so as they get more, existing ones will be discarded.

About workers and master builders
It’s a worker placement game but every player has 2 separate groups of figures. What the rules call "workers", but also 3 master builders. The master builders are the actual “workers” in terms of the worker-placement mechanism, and the other workers might be viewed more as a resource – so I’ll refer to them as meeples to avoid confusion.

Every round has 3 major parts:
- Players draft cards from 9 available ones. 2 of them are those craftsmen cards which have a cost and the others are cards that will allow getting resources later but also require you to send meeples to specific locations in the board (so you can’t take a card if you don’t have enough).
- There’s an interesting way to determine the order of the placement, but in the end, all players will have placed the master builders in different locations in the board.
Players need to notice they need to place a builder in locations where they sent the meeples in the previous phase to get the resources.
- All locations in the board are activated in order – they are numbered from 1-14.

Master builder placement phase:
How does the “master builder placement” phase done and how is order determined?
There’s a track going from 7 to 0. All master builders are mixed in a bag and pulled up one by one. The owners of the first 7 builders drawn will need to pay money if they want to place it right there and then on a location (once a location is occupied, then in general, it is blocked for other players). The price keeps dropping as more builders are drawn from 7 until it reaches 0 and then they are just placed.
However – if there's still a price to place the builder (the first 7 drawn), players can opt to pass. That means that master builder will wait in line until all master builders have been pulled from the bag, and only then it will be placed (for free), in the same order different players have passed.

What are the various numbered locations?
Locations #1 and #2 are together (as the #1 location isn’t really a worker placement location) – A card is drawn, it’s usually a negative effect. A player who placed a builder on the #2 location can choose to disregard the card or get a bonus resource.

Location #3 provides money according to the meeples you didn’t send out during the initial card phase.

Location #4 has two action cards (allowing placing 2 master builders) and you will get the card. It can be an immediate effect card, and ongoing effect or something you can trigger later.

Location #5 gives victory points (2 master builders can be placed there – the first one will get more points)

Location #6, 7 and 8 are resource locations – You get the promised resources from the cards you chose (and paid for by sending meeples).

Location #9 allows everyone to place master builders there – The first one to place it will get a rare metal resource, and any player who didn’t place there at all will need to pay taxes according to a dice roll.

Location #10 has two craftsmen cards allowing placing 2 builders – You get the card you placed next to, for free this time.

Location #11 provides 2 temporary meeples for next round.

Location #12 has a market with 4 of each regular resource and you can place up to 4 master builders there (even your own again) – According to placement order (and round and round again) you choose if to buy a single type of resource from the market, sell a single type of resource (to the bank), or pass and be done with this location altogether. You can sell metal here, but not buy one.

Location #13 doesn’t require placing master builders. It finally allows you to use your craftsmen cards to gain points from resources (each card provides a conversion rate but you cannot use it only a certain number of times). In the game’s arc you are contributing to building a cathedral (similarly to the story of the Ken Follet book “Pillars of the Earth”).

Location #14 gives the person who placed there his master builder the “first player” instead of the next person clockwise. The first player gets to draft cards first early in the round.

And that’s it… the game ends after the 6th round – tracked by placing six 3D cathedral pieces.

threads.title: I recommend The Pillars of the Earth

posts.author: Quantum_Jack
posts.body:
I recommend Pillars of the Earth. This classic of the worker placement genre is inspired by the book of the same title, and pits a few craftsmen against each other in the joint work of building one central construction project. Any products which contribute to the final build reward victory points and the most points at the end wins.

The innovation here comes from the unique turn order mechanism, which allows players to go early, but pay more for the privilege, or go late for free or cheap. Then once all workers are in position the spaces resolve in a pre-determined order. Funnily in this game in addition to workers for action selection, the players also have laborer pieces that can be sent out to gather resources of various types (wood, steel, stone, etc) in a less limited form than traditional worker placement.

The randomized event deck and the semi-random order in which the main production cards come out and are bid for provide plenty of variability to keep the game from being easily solvable. The market where you can buy and sell extra resources provides that extra little bit of consistency so you can usually get something done even if your preferred options aren't available during the main worker placement phase.

All in all it is a solid introduction to the genre on a beautifully illustrated board. The pieces are delightfully unique and the rules are simple enough to introduce to new gamers (it was literally my first worker placement game) but it adds enough freshness to keep you coming back for more. If you get a chance I highly suggest you check out Pillars of the Earth.

posts.body:
So we're saying roughly £100 per set, £226 for both + Mothra, and £286 for everything plus the luxury bonuses.
Wow. That's about a third more than I expected. On top of that there's a whole lot more FOMO than I was expecting, what with Mothra being a KS exclusive and the text of the campaign itself casting doubt over retail availability.
There was a post in the Unmatched subreddit discussing this where pretty much everybody participating voiced that the price tag was simply too high. A couple of these Redditors also pointed out that the high price tag effectively leads to non-American backers subsidising RG for the US tariffs given their pledge not to ever ask for extra funds from backers as a means to mitigate the tariffs effects. (This was a factor I absolutely had not considered as I had - maybe naively? - read RG's statement on the matter as altruistic).

Determining value for money in gaming (both video and tabletop) has arguably always been weird. In the past, for me to go in on a game costing over £100, it's gotta have extremely nice components, be very fun and provide a truly earthshaking experience (TI4 and those four letter Cole Werhle games fit this bill.) Granted I indulge in the Arkham Horror lcg which, as a "lifestyle" game has cost way more in the long run, but the experience and variety do enough to justify the costs in such "lifestyle" games (see also Warhammer, etc). I wouldn't call Unmatched a "lifestyle" game, but I'd say the same applies and I've certainly had my satisfaction out of my UM collection and feel it's money well spent.

So to the game at hand: is the Battle Monsters big bundle - which costs twice as much as Twilight Imperium + Prophecy of Kings - worthy enough of such a price tag?
There are five titans, four factions and four battlegrounds. Is that likely to provide enough variety to entertain for many years? Seems like less variety than either TR:V or Unmatched for multiple times the price... I think the real answer to this relies on tactical/strategic depth, but then how much room for that is there in a game of this type? It's not really like the OG Battle Masters was particularly deep in practice, maybe even less so than Risk...
How do you think the component count and quality for the price look to be stacking up to similar but cheaper RG ventures like Dark Tower and Thunder Road?

If you are a backer, how much did love of Battle Masters or Godzilla influence your decision? My deep and longstanding love of both is what keeps me on the precipice... If it was Heisei-era Godzilla & co, there would be no hesitation on my end at all (I don't think the Monsterverse will or can ever be as iconic as Showa or Heisei era Toho kaiju).

If you're outside of the US, how do you feel about RG's aforementioned pledge and the notion of non-US backers subsidizing US tariffs with increased prices? I don't feel like I'm economically literate enough to come to a conclusion on that matter.

Apologies if this post reads as muddled. I've got a LOT of complicated feelings about this right now and am very keen to see others' thoughts. Honestly I was hoping someone else would start this conversation as I'm a bit of a RG fanboy at this point...

Appreciate the conversation and folks checking out the campaign. And, of course, I can't speak to what price makes sense for any particular person. And folks are welcome to disagree with the choices we made, e.g., how big the Titans are. But I want to clarify two things.

First, non-US backers are not subsidizing tariffs. Period. The impact of tariffs at the time this is produced will be on how bit the print run is and if it makes it to hobby distribution. At 30%, yes. At 145%, no. As Stephen noted, there are really two choices when you're doing a campaign. You can either charge actual costs at the time of shipping or estimate and provide a flat rate. We prefer the latter so that our backers are never surprised by a second bill down the road.

Second, as I've stated in other places, every single publisher is setting their MSRP based on what the thing costs to make. If you're getting "more" in a game that has a lower MSRP, that's because what you are getting costs less to make. There's a secondary piece to that in a KS campaign that offers higher margins than distribution. So you might lower your price to backers against the MSRP or you might subsidize the shipping or through in bennies or whatever. But, at the end of the day, the price is a pretty standard multiplier of the cost. If, for example, CMON is giving you "more" in their Marvel United campaign at a cheaper price, either the "more" doesn't cost as much or they're charging more for shipping, or maybe they're getting better economies of scale on a title that is well proven, or whatever.

Like I said, I won't begrudge anyone for feeling the game isn't worth the price for them. Everybody has to make that choice for themselves with any game or any other purchase for that matter. I just feel like there's an insinuation that we're taking advantage of folks or price gouging or something, and that's not the case.

threads.title: Flamecraft Duals - Designer Diary: Manny Vega

posts.author: Kegatron
posts.body:
Hey everybody, let’s get the formalities out of the way, this is Manny Vega the designer of Flamecraft and Flamecraft Duals. I’m not usually out at the front of the Kickstarter campaigns, preferring to sit back and make puns, poems and cryptic clues about future plans. That said, I thought that the origins of Flamecraft Duals (and the dubious grammar choice) deserved a little bit of a story. Now, keep in mind this is just a tale about how the game came to be designed, but I know you’re all here for some art reveals so let’s get desert first!


The short version of the story goes like this: Peter asked if I had any ideas for a smaller game we could set in the Flamecraft universe and I lied and said, "yes!" I mean it wasn’t fully a lie because I have MANY designs in my notebook, but it’s not like I knew for sure that any would work for Flamecraft.

Quick side note here, the first thing I bought with money from Flamecraft was a ReMarkable digital notebook. I was so high on the success that all I wanted to do was start designing more games and I needed a place to store all my insanity. Currently I have over 1000 pages of notes just filled with ideas for “Flamecraft 2” going all the way back to February of 2022. I read through all of my notes and NOTHING in there was going to work as a smaller game! Expansion, sure. Huge new game with bell and whistles, also that. Small and Flamecraft were not in my mind. It would, however, spark the flame for the name, but I digress.

The longer story is that there was an event Cardboard Alchemy had been invited to participate in, and the time frame was very short. The thing is they were at the end of shipping Andromeda’s Edge and in the middle of shipping Critter Kitchen, not to mention developing things like FlameBound and other things I’m not supposed to talk about. Meanwhile, I’m 1000 pages into Flamebound and wrapping up Tea Witches, so the smart answer would have been, “we can’t do this right now.” Clearly, we are not one’s to make the smart choice and instead we DOUBLED down!

My magic notebook has many, many pages and I can make folders and copy things, move them around, it’s very cool. The big folder is Flamecraft, but another folder is just called Ideas, so I delved in to see what I could find. There are quite a few card games, some dice chuckers and even something about tossing pigeons, but the one idea that caught my eye I had named Tic-Tac-Foe. It was a bag draw game where all the player’s tokens were in the same bag and you played what you got and activated powers to prevent each other from scoring 4 in a row.



You can see the basic bones of Duals here, even the adorable dragon token that consumed an entire stack of anything it was placed on 😅. This idea was born BEFORE Flamecraft, but something about it never quite worked. It was overly thinky, and often your choices interfered with other players but did not help you in a meaningful way. Soon after I would find myself diving headfirst into Flamecraft design and this fell away, but never forgotten.

The game was already set-up in TTS, so it was easy to put some cute dragons on the tokens, use the village for a board and test the idea out quickly. It 100% did not work, but unlike Tic-Tac-Foe I instantly saw what the problem was. Flamecraft is all about sharing things, NOT owning the dragons and “gently removing” all others. This change in perspective led me to the idea of matching 3 dragons in a row, which was a perfect mirror for the 3 dragons in a shop. This meant almost every token could be used by either player to make progress and had a nice shared feel. From there it was easy to make a deck of shops, and the pieces literally fell into place.



The ideas for the individual powers of each dragon was actually pretty easy, I had already worked out several abilities for the other game I just needed them to not discard things. This had the added benefit of giving the game a definite end which was sorely lacking in Tic-Tac-Foe. I spent a RIDICULOUS amount of time picking the abilities that best fit the artisan types, and rewording them to fit the gameplay and theme. For example, I knew I needed ways to draw tokens and Crystal had to be “draw 3 and keep 1” because of course the Crystal artisan gained 3 different goods, so three was very important!

I played the game with my kids and a few close friends to make sure it worked, and I am very happy to say it was humming along quite quickly. I also played with Sandara and she actually enjoyed it out of the gate (a true first for me 😀), but we agreed it needed something else. A hook of some kind, something new to add to the world of Flamecraft. That’s when I remembered my notes on page 147, where there was an idea for expansion hybrid dragons.



This is the first instance, the first power ideas and first names I jotted down, and they have since changed quite a bit. I can't remember exactly why we never pursued this further, but I guess it was just waiting for the perfect place to reveal itself. This gave me the idea to add DUAL dragons (pun intended) to the game, and it just felt perfect that this 2-player game of friendly duels would bring new (old) dragons to Flamecraft!






Along with the dual dragons I had added some fancy dragon tokens, coins and statues into the bag for advanced play. These would trigger when drawn, and had their own special rules, but they would be honed and refined with playtesting as Luke and Peter tried desperately to reign in my love of chaos. I also went from a grid to a hex pattern that allowed for much smoother movement and a wonderful floor pattern. It didn’t take long as far as game development goes, but it did take too long to be part of the original event. Luckily people were enjoying the game so much, Cardboard Alchemy decided to put it directly into the schedule and here we are.



The moral of the story is that in game design, NEVER throw anything away. More importantly, never stop thinking about the different ways you can use and improve your ideas. You never know what pieces you will be able to use if another opportunity randomly crops up when you least expect it.

Thanks for all the support you all have given Flamecraft and Duals. It's been an absolute pleasure to work on this game and I really can't wait to get it into everyone's hands.

posts.author: Myoman
posts.body:
The game is so difficult that I can't even enjoy all it has to offer as everyone only has 1 action by turn 3. I can't even make a fitting and use it until the next turn, and by that time there is too much snowballing negative statuses to do any actions whatsoever. I need to have some semblance of agency to have a balance of tension.

Take a look at Psycho Raiders by EofEE. The game is literally founded on the idea that the good guys are going to lose. It's how close you can come with impossibile odds. It hits the sweets spot because it gives the good guys just enough agency to think they have a chance. Here, unless you follow an extremely rigid strategy, you fail. You don't have enough ability to explore the game and become engaged with your characters enough before they meet a tragic end.

In the game The Village, you feel a certain sense of loss when your meeples die because they gave you a consistent benefit before they died. Therefore you value them. If you can't do enough to use a character before they die because they have only 1 action by turn 2, you won't develop that value. This game plummets you downhill so fast you don't get time to explore the characters and let them create value by their actions.

1. Everyone starts with hunger 1.
2. Starting supplies: +1 water + 1 knife.
3. The fireman comes with a hatchet. (I spent 4 turns trying to build that f*cking thing last game).
4. No 1st event.
5. Sleeping in a bed at night can prevent an increase in illness.
6. Two people to a bed (spooning).

That's it. That should give me enough room to do enough to get a head start and explore how to play the game. After I get better I'll go back to the old rules.
